questions.question: According to the 'Power of the Sub-Niche' principle in Lesson 1, why is a Pediatric Nutrition Coach specializing in 'Pickey Eating for Children with ADHD' likely to see higher conversion rates than a generalist?
options: Generalists are perceived as too expensive by most families
Specialization reduces the 'Customer Acquisition Cost' (CAC) by targeting a specific pain point with higher perceived authority
Most insurance providers only cover sub-specialized nutrition coaches
Families with ADHD children are statistically more likely to use social media for health advice
questions.explanation: Specialization allows a coach to speak directly to a specific pain point, which increases perceived authority and trust, leading to lower marketing costs and higher conversion rates.

questions.question: In Lesson 2, what is the critical difference between Professional Liability Insurance and General Liability Insurance for a nutrition coach?
options: General Liability covers dietary advice, while Professional Liability covers office injuries
Professional Liability (Errors & Omissions) protects against claims of negligence in your advice; General Liability covers physical accidents like slips and falls
There is no difference; they are interchangeable terms in the coaching industry
Professional Liability is only required for coaches working in hospitals
questions.explanation: Professional Liability (E&O) is essential for coaches as it protects against claims arising from the professional advice provided, whereas General Liability covers physical premises-related accidents.

questions.question: When designing a 'High-Ticket' program (Lesson 3), which pricing strategy is most effective for ensuring client compliance and long-term results?
options: Pay-per-session pricing to allow families flexibility
Monthly subscriptions with no end date
Transformation-based package pricing (e.g., 90-day 'Gut Health Reset') with a flat fee
Sliding scale fees based on the child's age
questions.explanation: Transformation-based packages shift the focus from 'hours' to 'outcomes,' which increases client commitment and ensures they stay for the duration required to see physiological changes.

questions.question: A 2023 analysis of social media engagement for health professionals (Lesson 4) found that which type of content generates the highest 'Save' rate among parents?
options: Promotional posts offering 20% off coaching calls
Personal photos of the coach's own children
Educational 'Infographics' or 'Carousels' that solve a specific problem (e.g., '5 Iron-Rich Snacks')
Long-form video testimonials from previous clients
questions.explanation: Educational, 'saveable' content provides immediate value and establishes the coach as a reliable resource, which is a key step in the content marketing funnel.

questions.question: During a discovery call (Lesson 5), a parent says, 'I need to talk to my spouse before committing.' What is the most effective 'Sales Mastery' response?
options: Tell them the offer expires in 24 hours to create urgency
Ask, 'If your spouse says yes, are you 100% ready to start, or are there other concerns we should discuss now?'
Offer a 50% discount if they sign up without talking to the spouse
End the call immediately and wait for them to email you
questions.explanation: This response identifies whether the spouse is the real objection or if there are underlying hesitations about the program itself that the coach can address.

questions.question: Which automation tool is cited in Lesson 6 as the most effective for reducing 'No-Show' rates in a coaching practice?
options: Automated email newsletters
SMS (Text) appointment reminders sent 24 hours and 1 hour before the session
Automatic billing and invoicing systems
AI-driven chatbots on the website
questions.explanation: Studies show that SMS reminders significantly reduce no-show rates compared to email-only reminders, as they have much higher open rates.

questions.question: When networking with pediatricians (Lesson 7), what is the most valuable 'Leave-Behind' a coach can provide to the doctor's office?
options: A stack of the coach's business cards
A 50-page ebook on pediatric nutrition
A one-page 'Referral Form' or 'Co-Management Template' that makes it easy for the doctor to track the patient's progress
A box of healthy snacks for the office staff
questions.explanation: Pediatricians value efficiency. A co-management template shows professional competence and makes the referral process seamless for the medical provider.

questions.question: In the 'Scaling Your Impact' lesson (Lesson 8), what is the primary advantage of a 'Hybrid' coaching model (Group + 1:1) over a pure 1:1 model?
options: It requires more hours of work for the coach
It allows the coach to lower the entry price point while increasing the 'Profit Per Hour' (PPH)
It removes the need for any legal contracts
It is the only way to get insurance reimbursement
questions.explanation: Hybrid models allow coaches to serve more people at once (scaling) while maintaining a high-touch element, significantly increasing the coach's hourly earnings.

questions.question: According to HIPAA guidelines discussed in Lesson 2, which of the following is REQUIRED if you use a third-party app to store client health data?
options: A signed 'Business Associate Agreement' (BAA) with the software provider
A written recommendation from a doctor to use that specific app
A minimum of 1024-bit encryption on your personal phone
The app must be hosted on a government-owned server
questions.explanation: A BAA is a legal requirement under HIPAA that ensures the third-party provider also adheres to privacy and security standards for protected health information (PHI).

questions.question: A case study in Lesson 3 showed that families in a '90-Day Feeding Success' program had a 40% higher success rate than those in 'Pay-As-You-Go' coaching. Why?
options: The 90-day families were given free supplements
The structured timeline creates psychological 'sunk-cost' commitment and allows for physiological habit formation
The coach worked more hours with the 90-day families
Pay-As-You-Go families were not allowed to ask questions via email
questions.explanation: Long-term commitment (90 days) provides the necessary time for behavioral and physiological changes to take root, whereas per-session clients often drop out before seeing results.
